channel.title: NYT > Climate and Environment
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: How the National Park Service Is Deleting American History
item.description: Philadelphia sued the Trump administration after it directed the Park Service to rip out a memorial to slavery. Elsewhere, materials about climate change and labor history were being removed.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow and Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:credit: Rachel Wisniewski for The New York Times
item.media:description: A visitor to the removed signs at the National Historical Park in Philadelphia on Friday.

item.title: Storm Poses Big Threats to Power Grids Across U.S.
item.description: Managers of electric grids say freezing temperatures and ice and snow could lead to power outages in many places, potentially leaving millions in the dark.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Joel Bissell/Kalamazoo Gazette, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Heavy snow and freezing rain can weigh down tree branches and power lines, causing equipment failures that can often cripple power systems.

item.title: An Antarctic Mission to Recover a Robot’s Data
item.description: In the unforgiving polar wilderness, scientists go to great lengths to safeguard the devices that gather precious data.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: New U.S. Rule Aims to Speed Up Mining of the Seafloor
item.description: The Metals Company, a prominent seabed-mining company, applauded the change and filed a new application more than doubling the area it hopes to mine.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A ship chartered by the Metals Company to explore the viability of mining the seabed in the Pacific in 2021.

item.title: How Does Climate Change Affect Winter Storms?
item.description: A warmer atmosphere has the potential to hold more moisture, which can contribute to heavier precipitation in any season, scientists say.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:credit: Aristide Economopoulos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Snow falling in Montclair, N.J., on Sunday.

item.title: 430,000-Year-Old Wooden Tools Are the Oldest Ever Found
item.description: The finding, along with the discovery of a 500,000-year-old hammer made of bone, indicates that our human ancestors were making tools even earlier than archaeologists thought.
item.dc:creator: Franz Lidz

item.title: Power Outages Could Rise as Freezing Temperatures Persist After Winter Storm
item.description: Electrical grids appeared to have handled the storm over the weekend relatively well, but energy experts said the risk of more outages remained.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: William DeShazer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Most power outages resulted from snow piling up on electrical equipment and ice dangling from trees and power lines.

item.title: What Is Thundersnow, One of Weather’s Rarest Spectacles
item.description: A clap of thunder can come as a surprise in the steady calm of falling snow. Here’s what causes it.
item.dc:creator: Camille Baker

item.title: Is Climate Change Weakening the Polar Vortex?
item.description: Rising Arctic temperatures and melting sea ice could be causing cold air to flow into the Northern Hemisphere. But not all scientists agree.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: Jalen Wright for The New York Times
item.media:description: A study found that the stretching of the polar vortex was linked to increased severe winter weather in the United States in the past decade.

item.title: How a Year of Trump Changed Britain
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer stood firm over Greenland. But his center-left government and the country as a whole have been buffeted by President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and Prime Minister Keir Starmer at Chequers, near London, in September during Mr. Trump’s state visit to Britain. During the debate over Greenland, Mr. Trump has had sharp words for Mr. Starmer.

item.title: Setting Foot on the Melting Thwaites Glacier
item.description: Bad weather ​delayed expedition scientists’​ ​efforts to set up camp on Thwaites Glacier ​in Antarctica ​and take measurements ​to determine how quickly it is melting. After the skies cleared, our journalists​, Raymond Zhong and Chang W. Lee​, took us along for their first steps on Thwaites.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Christina Thornell, Jon Miller and Stephanie Swart

item.title: Winter Storm Forecast: 5 Key Things to Know Across the US
item.description: Here are five key things to know about the forecast.
item.dc:creator: Amy Graff
item.media:credit: Joel Bissell/Kalamazoo Gazette, via Associated Press

item.title: Energy Dept. Says It Is Canceling $30 Billion in Clean Energy Loans
item.description: Many of the cancellations had been known for months, but the announcement underscored the drastic change in the energy landscape under President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Energy Department canceled a partial loan guarantee to Sunnova Energy, a residential solar panel installer that was experimenting with a novel way to link home solar and battery systems.

item.title: Alfred McLaren, 93, Dies; Submariner Led Secret Cold War Missions
item.description: He participated in the first baseball game at the North Pole. Later, he became an expert in the impact of climate change on Arctic ice sheets.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: E.P.A. Revives Plan to End Testing on Animals by 2035
item.description: Lee Zeldin, the E.P.A. administrator, revived a plan created during the first Trump administration to end the testing of chemicals on mammals.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Ryan M. Kelly/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Trump administration’s goal has been to move faster to adopt alternatives to animal testing, like computer programs. But experts say methods like computer models do not produce the same level of information.

item.title: At Davos, Talk of Climate Change Retreats to the Sidelines
item.description: The annual gathering of top business leaders and policymakers used to be a center of the global climate movement. Things are much more complicated now.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Fabrice Coffrini/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: At the Davos forum in recent years, the focus on climate change and stopping biodiversity loss has taken a back seat to issues like cryptocurrency, artificial intelligence and geopolitics.

item.title: Why Climate Isn’t a Top Business Priority at Davos
item.description: The World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, was once ground zero for an unofficial climate movement in the business community. David Gelles, a climate reporter for The Times, describes why climate is no longer a key focus in Davos today.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles, Gilad Thaler, Leila Medina, June Kim and Christina Shaman

item.title: National Park Service Removes Sign on Climate Change From Fort Sumter
item.description: The historic site, on an island in South Carolina, could be inundated by rising seas in decades to come. A display on the threat has been removed.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Enrico Della Pietra/Alamy
item.media:description: Fort Sumter, in the harbor off Charleston, S.C. President Trump has ordered the Park Service to review plaques and other materials presented to visitors at 433 sites around the country.

item.title: The New Wild Card on Travelers’ Itineraries: Uncertainty
item.description: Politics, military action and climate change have increased risk for destinations that once seemed like sure bets, forcing travelers to change how they plan.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root
item.media:credit: Tim Cook

item.title: Rising Global Temperatures May Affect Choices for Winter Olympic Venues
item.description: Future games will need to be held at higher altitudes, and spread over multiple venues in order to adapt to a changing climate, new research suggests.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: Maja Hitij/Getty Images
item.media:description: Gus Schumacher, a member of the U.S. cross-country skiing team, left, competing in Planica, Slovenia, in March 2023.

item.title: What’s a Human Life Worth? The E.P.A. Says Zero Dollars.
item.description: The Environmental Protection Agency has stopped estimating the dollar value of lives saved in the cost-benefit analyses for new pollution rules.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.category: Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs (US)
item.media:credit: Bettmann/Getty Images
item.media:description: Los Angeles smog in 1979. For decades, government agencies have used a theoretical value of human life when calculating the costs and benefits of new regulations.

item.title: All Sides Agreed on Shutting a Coal Plant. Then Trump Stepped In.
item.description: The administration has thrown into chaos a deal that Washington State worked out with local leaders, environmentalists and industry.
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown
item.media:credit: Evan McGlinn for The New York Times
item.media:description: The deal to shut a coal plant in Centralia, Wash., was held up as an example of how to phase out fossil fuels in a way that balances seemingly opposed interests.

item.title: Forecasters Warn of a Major Storm Brewing for the South
item.description: One meteorologist warns that “the main ingredients” are fitting into place for a disruptive winter storm later this week.
item.dc:creator: Nazaneen Ghaffar
item.media:credit: Joel Bissell/Kalamazoo Gazette, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A driver in Ottawa County, Mich., on Monday. Severe cold is expected to continue in the Upper Midwest this week, and temperatures could drop even further.

item.title: At last, the team pitches tents on the Thwaites Glacier.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Araon, parked at the edge of the Thwaites.

item.title: Scientists Set Up Camp on Thwaites Glacier in Antarctica
item.description: Low clouds have lifted long enough for helicopters to ferry scientists and their gear to a fast-melting glacier on the edge of Antarctica.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Democrats Seek Investigation of $3.5 Million Deal by Interior Official’s Husband
item.description: Records show that Karen Budd-Falen, a top Interior Department official, didn’t disclose a contract between her husband and the developers of a mine approved by the agency.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Mead Gruver/Associated Press
item.media:description: Karen Budd-Falen in 2017. Ms. Budd-Falen, currently the third-ranking official at the Interior Department, also worked at the agency during the first Trump administration.

item.title: Cows Use Tools, Too, New Study Finds
item.description: A pet cow named Veronika can scratch her own back with a broom — the first scientifically documented case of tool use in cows, researchers say.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: Explore a century of The Times’s reporting from Antarctica.
item.media:credit: Malcolm W. Browne/The New York Times
item.media:description: Adélie penguins on Torgerson Island in 1991.

item.title: A Look Through a Century of Times Reporting From Antarctica
item.description: Generations of Times journalists have journeyed there with scientists. Their coverage traces humankind’s changing relationship with the most mysterious continent.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: The New York Times, St. Louis Post-Dispatch
item.media:description: One of the dog teams of the Byrd Expedition resting in the foothills near the Axel Heiberg Glacier on the Ross Ice Shelf in Antarctica in 1930.

item.title: A Century of The New York Times in Antarctica
item.description: Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong takes a trip into the New York Times archives to see how our understanding of Antarctica has changed over the past century.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Kassie Bracken, Christina Thornell, David Seekamp, Stephanie Swart, Phil Caller, Chang W. Lee and Nikolay Nikolov

item.title: Kristina Gjerde, Advocate for Ocean Biodiversity, Dies at 68
item.description: She played a key role in negotiating a landmark United Nations treaty to protect the high seas, an agreement that went into effect this weekend.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel

item.title: World’s First Treaty to Protect the High Seas Becomes Law
item.description: Over two decades after negotiations began, the High Seas Treaty is designed to protect biodiversity in international waters by enabling conservation zones.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.category: United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity
item.media:credit: Jakub Gojda/Alamy
item.media:description: The High Seas Treaty represents the first time that the vast majority of international waters, which lie outside of any country’s jurisdiction and cover nearly half the globe, can be protected.

item.title: How Wall Street Turned Its Back on Climate Change
item.description: Six years after the financial industry pledged to use trillions to fight climate change and reshape finance, its efforts have largely collapsed.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Climate activists protest BlackRock in New York City in 2023.

item.title: The $2 Rental Batteries Helping to Power South Africa
item.description: The batteries offer an affordable system for those who lack reliable power and the money to buy their own solar panels.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Joao Silva
item.media:credit: Joao Silva/The New York Times
item.media:description: Anselmo Mugabe, in stripy shirt, who runs a hair Salon in Thembisa, a township north east of Johannesburg, uses the BPowerD batteries in order to run his business.

item.title: Thousands Evicted From Makoko, the ‘Venice of Nigeria’
item.description: Community leaders in Lagos say evictions in the name of development have left many residents of this fishing village homeless.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey and Taiwo Aina
item.media:credit: Taiwo Aina for The New York Times
item.media:description: At the Makoko community, in Lagos, this week.

item.title: Edison Files Claims Against Los Angeles County and Others on Eaton Fire
item.description: Southern California Edison said its equipment most likely started the Eaton fire but asserted that government agencies and other businesses shared liability for the devastation.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Eaton fire killed 19 people and destroyed more than 9,400 buildings in Southern California.

item.title: An Antarctic Icebreaker Takes a Pioneering Sail
item.description: Part of Pine Island Glacier collapsed several years ago, forming an unstable inlet where no ship had sailed. Until now.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Supreme Court to Decide if the Pesticide Roundup Is Shielded From Lawsuits
item.description: The case could affect thousands of claims that the widely used weedkiller causes cancer.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick and Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Goss Images, via Alamy
item.media:description: Roundup, used widely on cropland, has faced controversy over its effects on human health.

item.title: Virginia Coastal Offshore Wind Project Can Continue, Judge Rules
item.description: Construction can continue on an $11.2 billion project off the coast of Virginia, said to be 70 percent complete.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Steve Helber/Associated Press
item.media:description: Wind turbine components at a staging area for the Coastal Virginia Offshore Wind project in Portsmouth, Va., last month.

item.title: Preparing to drill into a glacier
Why Some NYCHA Residents Are Getting Induction Stoves
item.description: A pilot program in Housing Authority apartments will offer the trendy stoves, which improve air quality and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
item.dc:creator: Hilary Howard
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Wants to Halt Almost All Coal Plant Shutdowns. It Could Get Messy.
item.description: Even as administration officials vowed this week to head off scheduled retirements, some aging plants are now breaking, and costs could run to the billions.
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown and Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Brittany Peterson/Associated Press
item.media:description: A coal-burning unit at the Craig Generating Station had been set to close since 2016, but the Energy Department has ordered that it stay open.

item.title: The Cities That Broke Heat Records Last Year
item.description: Thousands of cities around the world saw their hottest year on record in 2025 as the planet has inched closer to a key temperature threshold.
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown
item.media:credit: Go Nakamura/Reuters
item.media:description: Shanghai was one of thousands of cities that set records for average annual temperatures since 1950.

item.title: State and Federal Lawmakers Want Data Centers to Pay More for Energy
item.description: Despite many proposals, there is little consensus among governors, lawmakers and tech executives about exactly how much the companies behind data centers should pay for electricity.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Karen Weise
item.media:credit: Scott Ball for The New York Times
item.media:description: A data center built by OpenAI and Oracle in Abilene, Texas.

item.title: Empire Wind Project Can Resume Construction, Judge Rules
item.description: A federal judge said the Empire Wind project off Long Island would suffer “irreparable harm” if the Trump administration continued to hold up work.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation and Enforcement
item.media:credit: Equinor, via Reuters
item.media:description: The South Brooklyn Marine Terminal, the staging site for the Empire Wind offshore wind project.

item.title: How One Company, Neptune Flood, Is Pushing a Private Takeover of Flood Insurance
item.description: For half a century, a federal program has covered most at-risk properties. Now, a private company is pitching a plan to shrink the government’s role.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance
item.media:credit: Mike Belleme for The New York Times
item.media:description: A home in Swannanoa, N.C., that was damaged by flooding from Hurricane Helene in 2024.

item.title: A Look at Antarctica From Above
item.description: After nearly two weeks at sea without being able to launch his drone, New York Times photographer Chang W. Lee finally captures Antarctica from the air.
item.dc:creator: Chang W. Lee, Raymond Zhong, Jon Miller, Christina Thornell and Leila Medina

item.title: Weather Detours a Scientific Expedition to Antarctica’s Thwaites Glacier
item.description: Bad weather has postponed attempts to set up camp on the Thwaites Glacier. So researchers got onto the sea ice and met a local.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Toby Kiers, World Champion of Mycorrhizal Fungus
item.description: This year’s recipient of the Tyler Prize for Environmental Achievement talks about “punk science,” microbial economics and thinking like a mycorrhizal fungus.
item.dc:creator: Alan Burdick
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times

item.title: Britain Awards Wind Farm Contracts That Will Power 12 Million Homes
item.description: The British government provided guaranteed electricity prices to a group of wind farm developers in what it says is an effort to bring down power costs for consumers.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Suzie Howell for The New York Times
item.media:description: A wind turbine farm in East Anglia, England, in 2020. On Wednesday, the British government said it would provide guaranteed electricity prices for a group of wind farms off England, Scotland and Wales.

item.title: Why Greenland Matters for a Warming World
item.description: The fate of the world’s largest island has outsize importance for billions of people on the planet, because as the climate warms, Greenland is losing ice. That has consequences.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: Evgeniy Maloletka/Associated Press
item.media:description: A frozen sea inlet outside Nuuk, Greenland, last year. In the 12 months ending on Aug. 31, 2025, Greenland lost 105 billion metric tons of ice, scientists say.

item.title: U.S. Refiners to Profit as Trump Asserts Control Over Venezuelan Oil
item.description: The companies that turn oil into gasoline and diesel are likely to benefit more, right away, than the businesses that pump oil out of the ground.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Valero Energy refinery in Houston. U.S. refining companies are poised to profit if more Venezuelan oil starts flowing to the United States.

item.title: China’s Coal Ban Improved Air Quality, but Villagers Are Paying the Price
item.description: China banned the burning of coal for heat around Beijing, but natural gas subsidies have run out, leaving many villagers vulnerable in dangerously cold weather.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of a village in Quyang County, in northern China, soak up the midday sun to try to warm up and reduce their heating costs.
